Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-PSBR: Microalgae Lab-on-Chip Photobioreactor Platform for Genetic Screening and Metabolic Analysis Leading to Scalable Biofuel Production
Award.AbstractNarration:
EFRI-PSBR: Microalgae Lab-on-Chip Photobioreactor Platform for Genetic Screening and Metabolic Analysis Leading to Scalable Biofuel Production
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
The multi-disciplinary research team will develop microfluidic lab-on-chip devices with capabilities to precisely assay and manipulate parallel samples at single-cell resolution. The devices will enable the integration of multiple experimental parameters on a single user-friendly platform. These devices will then be used to analyze and optimize the growth and hydrocarbon production potential of an engineered recombinant photosynthetic microalgae. The specific test case will be a recombinant, fast growing Chlamydomonas reinhardtii algal strain that will be engineered to express a high-yielding hydrocarbon biosynthetic gene system derived from the slow-growing microalaga, Botryococcus braunii. These specific hydrocarbons produced by these organisms are of particular interest because they can be readily converted into petroleum-equivalent fuels.

BROADER IMPACTS
The proposed research will have broad scientific impact because the developed microfluidic platforms will directly contribute to and dramatically accelerate research and development in the general area of microbe-mediated biofuel and biometabolite production. Educational outcomes will include training of the next generation of microbial bioenergy engineers and scientists through research, involving undergraduate and minority students, local high school students, and high-school teachers in conjunction with existing programs at the participating institutions to provide them with early exposure to science and engineering. This project will allow students from multiple disciplines (engineering, microbiology, biochemistry) to interact and gain first hand experience in interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microalgae have demonstrated potential as a sustainable renewable energy solution. However, significant improvements in oil production, biomass growth, processability, energy efficiency, and ultimately cost-effectiveness are still required. Microfluidic systems, small devices that have tens of micrometer-scale channels through which liquid samples can flow through, allow controlling and moving cells one at a time rapidly and accurately, so has the potential to revolutionize how biotechnology research and development are conducted in the future. Application of these devices to microalgae could rapidly reveal critical information needed for improving the production of transportation-grade hydrocarbon by these cells. Our vision is that combining the development of such next-generation microdevices and genetic engineering of microalgae will result in new strategies for economically competitive liquid biofuel production from sunlight and carbon dioxide, as well as other bioproducts of high value.

 

The project strategy was to transfer the valuable hydrocarbon production pathway of the slow-growing alga Botryococcus braunii into faster-growing algae with commercial potential. B. braunii hydrocarbons are of particular value because they can be readily converted into petroleum-equivalent fuels, however the slow growth of this microalga makes it economically not viable. The project strategy was achieved through both technological and scientific advancements. From the technological advancement perspective, several microfluidics devices that allow rapid research and development in microalgae biotechnology were developed through this project. These include: a small palm-size microfluidic device that allows rapidly testing several tens of different cultivation conditions and how they impact the growth and oil production capability of microalgae in a single experiment; microfluidic devices that can rapidly test millions of single microalgal cells for their individual growth and lipid production capabilities one cell at a time; and microfluidic devices that allow accurately measuring the lipid level of single microalgal cells with simple instrumentation. These microfluidic devices collectively have been successfully utilized to identify high-lipid-producing and fast-growing microalgal variants, along with the best cultivation conditions that results in the highest growth and lipid production rate. From a scientific advancement perspective, all enzymes necessary for the high-value botryococcene biosynthesis in a widely used algal species, Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, were identified, and utilized for the first successful expression of such genes in this species. In addition, limitations to the method were identified, which are expected to advance plant biotechnology by stimulating research to overcome these barriers to success.

 

In addition, a techno-economical and life cycle analysis model was developed to simulate commercial production and its economic and environmental footprint, i.e. its sustainability. Along with comparisons of micro-scale growth to pilot-scale growth of microalgae, these tools can be utilized to further understand and assess whether the various high-productivity microalgae strains can be produced in economically sustainable way.

This research has achieved broad scientific impacts because the microfluidic devices developed through this project are expected to greatly accelerate research and development across the broad area of biofuel and biomolecule production by a range of microbes. The educational impacts achieved includes training the next generation of microbial bioenergy engineers and scientists through research, and the involvement of undergraduate and minority students, local high school students, and high-school teachers in well-structured existing programs to provide them with early hands-on exposure to science and engineering. This project also allowed students from multiple disciplines (engineering, microbiology, biochemistry) to interact and gain first-hand experience in interdisciplinary research.
